results.title: Finding Will
results.creator_credit: Kym Levett, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As the keeper of historical artifacts for his family, Kym Levett recently visited the parts of France that were battlefields during the Great War. He took his two sons and his mission is to find the remains of his great, great Uncle Will Cundy who had died fighting during the war. This is a story of the journey to bring Private William Cundy home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kym Levett, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Dots and dashes
results.creator_credit: Jacob Romeril, Kevin Coughlin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Catching mumps just before his 18th birthday prevented Kevin Coughlin from joining the RAAF during the second World War. But thanks to his connections, he was able to get work as a Wireless Telegraphist. In the end, Kevin ended up with skills that made him unique. Naturally left handed, he was forced to tap out morse code with his right hand. This afforded him a dexterity that meant he could do morse code with his right hand and write with his left which made him invaluable. He tells of his time in Darwin and, later, on Peron Island in the Timor Sea.

results.title: When a job becomes a passion
results.creator_credit: John Balsillie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Major John Balsillie was first posted to Malaya during World War II, he became interested in World War II research and military history. It soon developed into a passion and he shipped off over 20 crates of war relics to the Australian War Memorial in Canberra. He talks of his subsequent visits during the 1960s and the second time he served, in Vietnam. This interest became a lifelong passion for John, for which he was recently awarded an MBE for services to the Australian War Memorial. John sees his role as providing a record of the brave soldiers who gave their lives for Australia.

results.title: Rwanda
results.creator_credit: Joanne Harding, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Joanne Harding was sent to Rwanda as part of the Australian Defence Force medical Support Force. She focuses on the part of her experience that affected her the most, the eyes of the children. She describes their eyes as pools of nothingness as they begin to accept war as part of their everyday life. In turn, Joanne begins to question the effectiveness of her role and that of the United Nations in bringing peace to this wartorn country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joanne Harding, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Sounds of silence
results.creator_credit: Cliff Richards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a Victorian war veteran, Cliff Richards encapsulates his experiences during the war through the various sounds that assailed him. Sounds of helicopters, loud noises and, the one he feared the most, the sound of silence. He considers what the different sounds signify both for him and others and the way the everyday sounds of today can echo the horrors of the past.

results.title: Sense of guilt
results.creator_credit: Robert English, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A psychological portrait of a man who’s life has been marred by the horrors of war, as seen by his son. The English family were aware that when George English came back to Australia after the war he was a changed man but it wasn’t until son Robert volunteered to go to Vietnam that feelings George couldn’t disguise any longer came to the fore. In telling his story of his voyage back to Australia and their detour through Java. it became clear that George had been hiding the profound sense of guilt about surviving the war when many of his colleagues didn’t.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert English, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: When war came to Australia
results.creator_credit: Bill Hosking, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A recent visit to Darwin with his son reminded Bill Hosking of the time that war came to Australia. As one of the men who defended Darwin during that time, he was instructed to keep the details of the attack secret. In 1942, Bill Hosking joined up and was shipped up to train in the Northern Territory. It was during this time that the air raids on Darwin took place. Bill shares his experiences because he believes that not many people today know the story of how Australia came under attack.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Hosking, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: A recent visit to Darwin with his son reminded Bill Hosking of the time that war came to Australia. results.title: An Interview with Arthur Harridge
results.brief_description: Even though Arthur Harridge believes each service being as important as the other, he was primarily an airforce man. He tells of leaving his home and loved ones aboard the Mariposa, bound for the United States and then Europe, where he experienced the horrors of war first hand. An emotional account of the horrors of war, the things that kept the soldiers going returning home and trying to forget.

results.title: An Interview with Alfred Maskell
results.brief_description: Alfred Maskell just wanted to see the world. In 1941, he joined the Australian army and was sent to Malaya. By the time he got there, it was clear the Australian forces were up against it, fighting a strong enemy with weaponry from the previous World War. By the end of the year they were captured by the Japanese and forced to perform many unsavoury tasks, from burying Chinese civilians to working on the Thai-Burma railway and, finally, in Japan where he stayed till the war ended. This is a story of the brutality that many prisoners of war suffered during World War 2.

results.title: Confession from the Commander's diary: a narration in five parts
results.creator_credit: Svetlana Voloshina, L. Semenova and Alexander Sokurov
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Observing the rituals, gestures and trance-like states of his crew, a naval Commander ponders his life. How did he get here? What went wrong? And right? Will he ever know light again? Probing the dark, unspecified seas, the ship becomes contemporary Russia: dazzling midnight snowstorms; plain human actions shaped by centuries of weariness and wanting; persistence; inquiry.
